Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a hazy honey color with a decent head of white foam.  The nose has a good bit of yeast and light  notes of pithy citrus.  The flavor has a rather unusual taste that I cant quite place.  It leans more towards the malty side with a little honey and yeast.  Its light on the palate with gentle notes of orange and flowers.  Rather tasty and well balanced.  Light body with a medium amount of smooth carbonation.  The finish is light and lingering with a touch of fruity citrus.  A pretty tasty brew and definitely worth a try!

On tap at Tylers, Durham. Slowly but surely, more Stillwater stuff is showing up here. Semi-cloudy amber pour with a somewhat spotty carbonation, leaving an inconsistent head. Very floral, almost perfumey nose in places, with the rye and spice coming on as almost an afterthought. Lively, spicey palate is enjoyable and tends to bring out more complexity in the flavors. Theres spicy wheat, grain, and herbal notes in there along with dry hops, bitter fruits, and a bright floral note in the finish. Very earthy and refreshing.

From a growler from Beverage World, Ft Oglethorpe GA. Cloudy orange, big white head. Smells fruity, bretty, and floral. I thought lavender, but I see on the description that it contains honeysuckle and heather. Im gonna call that close enough. Flavor is also floral and herbal, with some nice woody notes and some brown sugar, too. We liked it...

(750 ml bottle from Global Beverage) Pours cloudy orange-yellow with a large, rising off-white head. Aroma of spices and yeast. Mouthfeel smooth, light and refreshing. Flavor of spice and yeast, light caramel and pepper. Hint of citrus tang. Medium bitterness overlays and produces a bite in the finish.

A solid pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a four-finger thick, pale tan colored head.  The beer is a light amber hue that shows a brilliantly clear, pale amber tinged, full gold hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells floral and fruity with notes of hibiscus, red pears, perhaps a touch of floral apple and a general flower nectar that displays lots of honey-like notes.  This up front character is supported by some spicy white pepper notes, touches of ginger, a touch of mustiness and a solid phenolic character that is more spice than clove (though some of the latter too).

Spritzy and carbonated up front this serves as a nice foil to the ample sweetness; much of the latter is perceived, accentuated by the ample floral and fruit notes in the flavor.  Sweet fruit notes of hibiscus, Macintosh apple, some floral pear, a soft berry character, lots of flower nectar notes and of course a solid honey like character (without the medicinal sweetness that honey has though).  There is a slight spiciness towards the finish that has white pepper notes, a touch of young ginger, some phenolic notes in the finish that leans towards plastic perhaps a touch of clove and a slight mustiness.

The nose and the flavor lean a bit too much towards the fruity and floral side of things; it needs more spiciness and / or funkiness to balance out this super fruit and floral character that is on show so well in this beer.  This is a touch unbalanced, but in the end is pretty tasty; actually it really reminds me a lot of a Saison I made with Hibiscus, it too really needed some balancing funkiness or spiciness in it.  I wonder if the standard French Saison yeast was used in here, I find that this yeast doesnt supply the bite and balance that my favorite Saison yeasts are able to supply.

750mL bottle.  A hazy copper pour with tons of dark floaties and a HUGE meringue-like beige head on top.  A sour, yeasty aroma of lemons, wheat, floral notes, a light herbaceousness, berry esters, and a dusty funkiness.  Medium-bodied with an alternating crispness and creaminess.  Caramel, bubblegum, and Red Delicious apples upfront taste-wise.  An herbaceous/wheaty middle.  The finish is tangy/sour with some lemons, green apples, and berries.  There is a yeasty funkiness underneath all the way through.  Not bad at all.
Hazy dark yellow with a fluffy white head. Earthy musty and grainy aroma and taste with sweet fruit and light citrus on the back end.

750ml. bottle Purchased @ Carls Meat market, Kittery, ME. $10.99  Hazy orange poor in Snifter. Tiny thin head around the side of the glass. Nose of rye, floral hops and barnyard.  A chewy mouthfeel. Fuller body. Taste is floral citrus up front. Mid-sip get spices and rye. Finish is dry with no bitterness. A bit of funk lingers after it warms. This is pretty good stuff.
Some fruit/orange in the aroma. This is strange. Looks okay. The flavor is weird, and a bit good, but not great. Hard to define, but I wouldnt have again at the price.

Foggy orange/golden color with ivory sheen. Big peppercorn, bready dusty pale malt, dry spice aromas. Frothy light mouthfeel. Light pit fruit sweetness with dusty pale malt, dry herbs/spices, citrusy wheat flavors--good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours bright orange with a large fluffy white head and a sharp fruity aroma. There is an acidic light malt flavor with a bit of toffee and a dry spicy finish.

Hazy orange-peach with a massive lasting white head. Lots of apple and pear cider in the aroma, with bready grains, rye spice, and perfume like dough. Excellent bready dough yeast character in the flavor, with earthy herbals, mild cider, and nectar fruits. Medium body with awesome caressing, pillowy carbonation, finishing clean and somewhat dry.

Another nice beer from Stillwater - I love their labels.
Anyways, this little mistress was a good one.  Hazy golden in color, crisp green apple on the nose and the tongue.

Tap.  Pours hazy amber with a medium, fizzy white head, medium-short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heather, floral hops, Belgian yeast, cookie malt, and fruity esters.  Flavor is Belgian yeast, fruity esters, vinous, caramel and biscuit malt, light sugar, floral hops, and a dry finish.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation.
murky amber, thinnest white ring for a head. Egg tea hay nose, lotion and Brett flavor, heavy bubblegum esters, bit plant stalk, watery finish. Fizzy, overly sweet, all over the place.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2011 The perfect summer quencher, this sexy debutante is spicy with strong floral notes, wheat malt and earthy barnyard yeast. Pours slightly hazy golden with nice white lace. Finishes with a lightly sweet tart long floral flourish.

Capped 750 from Malt & Vine. Pours hazy orange with a 3 finger creamy off-white head. Aroma of fresh citrus and mild stone fruits of the lighter sort. Backed by something suggesting barnyard. Med body. Flavor is rye malt, with citrus, a suggestion of honey, and a definite barnyard, with enough floral to notice. Its almost astringent, the edges of my tongue think a bit sour, and the back thinks a bit bitter. And it finishes pretty earthy/barnyard. No extremes, but a lot of flavor.

Cloudy golden pour with big quickly disappearing white head. floral, citrus, and farm funk nose. Mellow flavors unripe pear. Watery body.
Citrusy semisweet finish.
Good summer beer, nice sour notes. Great aroma with hints of raspberries. Didnt get much of the other notes mentioned in the beer.

Pour was a hazy orange/copper color. caramel toned, beautiful two fingers of cream-colored, yeasty head. Retained for most of the glass.

Amazing aromas of mellow orange-citrus, musty, grassy lemon, bread and Belgian fruits. Good funk to it, for sure.

First sip was very citrus-juicy in the middle, with a great imprint of musty funk from the nose. Rustic straw qualities, fresh cut grass, deep earthy moss notes on the exhale almost getting a smoky reverberation under the earthy herbal flavors that linger on that exhale. Amazing depth, and balanced complexity. Super crisp finish, medium bodied with great prickly carbonation.

Whole Foods, P st, DC 750ml ($12): Pours an orangish color with a small white head. Aroma is of flowers, yeast, a light fruitiness and some grain. Taste is pretty vibrant. Lots of floral aspects. Mild hopping throughout. There is something akin to a honey note somewhere in there as well. Pilsner malts or something like it are present in good force. Earthy tones are there. Really well-balanced and easy drinking. Mouthfeel has a high amount of carbonation, but it kind of accentuates all of the other flavors. Makes you happy to have a beer in your hand. Good stuff.

Pale golden pour thin white head light lacing ... aroma is faint and of grainy malts and some floral hops ..... taste is a nice floral and fruity yeast punch with some citrusy hops but more of a malty and grainy taste ... smooth mouthfeel a nice session beer but flavors are kind of weak

Shenandoah Throwdown, 2011.  Very hazy, almost opaque orange-yellow pour.  Good carbonation.  Light tan head.  Peppery and slightly grassy aroma.  Cotton candy flavor.  Dry and hoppy with a touch of tartness.  Peppery with a bitter finish.  Nice easy drinking.

750 mL bottle. Pours a hazy caramel color with a medium bubbly head. The aroma is oranges, cloves, caramel, rye, and notes of earthy and floral hops. The flavor is very sweet up front, with some bitterness and tartness coming forward in the finish. The palate is medium, chewy and clean. Light carbonation. Overall, this is a subtle and tasty beer.

750, capped and foiled. Pours a cloudy burnished medium amber with a dense and fizzy white head. Spotty bits of lace. Tangy funky nose, showing grass and wet hay. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Toffee, hay, grass, and caramel on the mid-palate. Light mineral touches here and there. Clean finish. Nice BdG.

750 ML Bottle-Cloudy golden pour w/a slight white head. Aroma of yeast & bread dough. Light & flavorful, yeast, bread dough, spice, floral hops, very earthy. Has a good bit of carbonation. Good brew, as usual from these guys!

Bottle: &nbsp Fiery amber, a bit hazy, moderate to large foamy off-white head, settles quickly leaving little lacing. &nbsp Meadow flowers, rye, and general farmhouse funkiness on the nose. &nbsp Smells great! &nbsp Soft sweetened floral notes right up front, very fresh and bright, followed by Honeysuckle and some very mild pale fruits. &nbsp I wish more Biere de Gardes were this fancy! &nbsp Vibrant on the tongue, with moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes just like it started, fresh cut meadow like flowers, bright barnish notes, with some very pale fruit aspects, melon, etc... &nbsp This was an unexpected treat on this hot September day. &nbsp Well done! &nbsp I would certainly reach for more given the chance.

750ml bottle: Pours a clear deep orange bronze with a spotty-lacing off-white head.  Has a sweet lightly toasted biscuity caramel nose with floral notes and light fruity esters.  Starts with good fullness and sweet chewy caramel malts with a nice light fruity complexity, some honey character and clove spice before a smooth and balanced bittersweet finish.  True to style and dangerously drinkable.

Draft @ hamiltons.  Pours a glowing and hazed orange with just a ring of white head.  Citrus and wheaty nose, chunky yeast and some orange.  Wheaty and chunky yeast in the flavors with orange essence around the edges and a phlegminess in the throat.  Clean and decent, just a bit overly phlegmy.

Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Yeast and earth aroma with spice. Yeast and citrus flavor with spice and earth. Medium bodied. Citrus and yeast lingers with light floral notes, light spice, and earth.

Sampled on 8/17/2011 at Beer Revolution. This Biere de Garde pours a slightly hazy medium orange gold color from the tap. Medium to large sized white foamy head, with nice retention. The aroma is fruity and sweet, spicy with a touch of tartness. A medium bodied Biere de Garde. The malts are fruity, yeasty and sweet. The hops are herbal and spicy. Nice carbonation. Clean and crisp tasting. Light and refreshing. A touch of spice lingers at the finish. Nice beer. Very easy drinking. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.

A - Pours a cloudy bright golden-orange color with a finger of thick frothy white head atop. the head fades slowly leaving behind lots of lace in the process.

S - Aroma is a complex mix of some banana yeast, some earthy and herbal spices, and some citrus and pineapple elements. There is also a bit of grain that comes through.

T - Starts off with a kick of banana yeasty flavor and some light spices. Through the middle, the spices get a bit richer with some more earthy and floral elements coming through. However, there is still a good balance provided by the citrus and yeast flavors. The finish is a mix of yeast, earthy and floral elements, spice, and a citrus that all linger together.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The beer felt very smooth and quite dry which made it very refreshing.

D - Very drinkable. The spices here were very complex and a bit different compared to most saisons. However, they wound up being well balanced and worked very well to deliver a great saison.

Served on draft at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a hazy orange color with a medium sized creamy white head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of spicy and earthy notes, citrus and banana and some floral notes. The taste is caramel, citrus, floral, honey, earthy notes and spices. Medium bodied. Nice.

Shenandoah Throwdown. 75cl bottle, thanks ryan.  Small off-white head, murky light amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, some spicy, peach, light funk.  Taste is moderately sweet, brad, peach, caramel, light spicy.  Light-medium body, light acidity.

20110824  750ml bottle from Honeygo.  Light amber color with tall, quick white head and aggressive carbonation, almost looks like a cream soda.  Aroma is very flowery with honeysuckle and green pepper predominant, plus some apple and cereal notes.  The Stillwater yeast is apparent and the aroma is reminiscent of Stateside, but less phenolic.  Heavily carbonated beer that keeps the mouthfeel airy and not at all cloying as you might expect from something categorized as a biere de garde.  Nice spiciness pervades throughout, and a very mild tang that lingers, but no bitterness.  Very enjoyable brew, and the Brewers art influence is apparent as a good complement to Stillwaters experimental nature without being weird or overly focused on specialty additions.

Tap at The Lions Pride. Served in a nice chalice. Pours a cloudy gold color with a cm-thick white head that leaves light lacing in the glass. Aroma of dusty grains, pepper, wheat, herbs, mixed fruits, and hibiscus. Flavor follows the aroma very much in step- fruity, herbal, grainy, spicy, wheaty. Light-bodied, with medium carbonation and a dry mouthfeel and crisp finish. So many herbs and spices are in this that almost none stand out.

750mL at Shenandoah Throwdown. Different beer from the tap version at Brewers Art. The pour is a hazy, glowing orange with a healthy, off-white head. Thick and dense. Nose is fresh apple with husky/raw grain. Taste is malty, heavy apple skin with red apple meal. Oatmeal grain comes through. Chalky, papery palate. Very raw grain forward.

Liquid tangerine pour with a solid ivory head that left sticky lacing behind.  Floral bouquet with honey, pepper and citrus coming through.  Flavor shows the honeysuckle along with lemongrass and a bit of caramel.  Medium mouthfeel

On tap. Pours with a hazed golden to orange hue with a lasting, foamy white head. Aromas are husky, bitter, floral, orange and lemon zest. Flavors are nutty, toasty, chestnuts, citrusy, estery, vanilla and apricot. Light phenols. Medium to lively bubbles with a dry finish.

Tap, Brickstore. Very cloudy straw orange yellow, with a pure white head. Musky, earthy, and light fruity aromas.  Bit earthy at first in the flavor, then white grapes, some minerals in the finish, slight grassiness. Lighter slick body with tight carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 Bottle picked up at SL. Bright orange color, small head. Nice flowery nose, along with some coriander, honey... Taste has a nice malt background with flowers, coriander, honeysuckle, some earth/dirt flavor. Very tasty. Medium body with above average carbonation level. Not sweet.....dry. Overall: Nice summer beer on a rainy day. Thanks robert!

A: The beer pours a fairly clear golden orange color with a finger of white head.

S: Very fruity, much more than I was expecting.  Theres a bit of pineapple and perhaps some passion fruit.  Really heavy on the bubblegum and yeast.  In fact, its a bit like Juicy Fruit.

T: The flavor is very much the same as the aroma.  Lots of bubble gum and sweet fruitiness to the flavor.  Juicy Fruit once again comes to mind.  A bit of bread and tropical fruit with a moderate yeastiness.

M: Medium bodied with a medium level of carbonation.

O: Though Ive liked some of the Stillwater saison, this was a bit too...estery for me.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a healthy white head.  Aroma has fairly mild floral notes with a bit of rye, nice light grain and a big musty earthiness.  Its nice and dry with a touch of spice and a bit more floral presence.  Good, fresh grain flavor.  Light feel.  Well carbonated.  A nice beer that manages to work in floral notes on a dry, earthy body.

(750ml bottle from Total Wine).  Pours a hazy golden/apricot color with dissipating off-white head and very active carbonation.  Aroma has lots of florals, honey, some spice and horseblanket.  Very pleasant.  Taste is sweet with more florals and rustic notes.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  A bit fizzy on the tongue.  Overall, this is a nice beer.

Bomber->snifter: Pours a rocky, off-white, quickly diminishing head atop a cloudy, amber body.  Aroma of effervesence (carbonation), banana, and caramel.  The body is thin, mildly acidic and astringent.  A strong burst of flavor as it first hits the palate, but it continues on like a typical American beer, then diminishes quickly.  Its different insofar as it doesnt lay around on the palate or overwhelm with hops, sweetness, etc., but somehow its enjoyable.  I would categorize this a good warm weather beer.

Draught at Whole Foods Devon:  Aroma of saison yeast, slight flowers, and slight grains.  Poured amber/gold in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of saison yeast, heather, honeysuckle, slight rye, slight spice, and slight fruit.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, yeast, slight fruit finish is dry.

Draft at Haymarket. How this is a BdG, I have no idea. Pours an attractive gold with a slight haze and sticky white foam. Nose is nice with a graininess, light citrus and floral perfume notes as well. Soft yeasty phenolics come through as well. On taste, it is a quite dry beer with a strong grainy notes and some round citrus. Pretty solid beer overall and a good one from Stillwater.
Draft, pours hazed golden white head. Nose is rather yeast, touch musty, sweet candy sugar, and lemons. Flavors are sweet lemons, yeasty, almost corny. Rather sweet and rough.

This truely has a barnyard nose.  Also has citrus in the aroma.  There is an earthy honey sweetness that is well balanced with the orange and lemon flavors.  It has a very soft full palate.  Above all I enjoy the freshness that wouldnt be found with an imported Biere de Garde that has suffered the fate of traveling so far from their homes in Europe.  The finish is dry.  Overall the beer is refreshing and has restorative qualities.

Picked up at Whole Foods on P St. NW in DC. Served in a Mikasa tulip.
Pours a mostly-clear light orange-ish color with a 1.5-finger white head and some good spotty lacing on the way down. The nose carries quite a bit of saison yeast and accompanying spice plus a little bit of citrus and light malt. Flavor has a touch of malt as the backing plus spice and citrus; light pepper and herbs throughout. Light to medium body with good carbonation. Nice brew, but not my favorite from Stillwater. Still, definitely worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Pouring from the Stillwater table during the festival at BCTC.  Pours a hazed gold with a medium sized white head.  Lightly floral citrus on the nose, lemon and almost a hint of sage. Maybe lavender?  Musky, wheat and nice toast.  Funky yeast, gorgeously musky, lemony and a big soft yeast finish.  Yummy stuff.

BCTC 2011, waited too long & missed out on the chardonnay barrel stateside. cloudy golden pour, lighter aroma with notes of tangerine. sweet flavor, tangerine, fruity. not as complex as previous stillwater beer Ive had but still pretty solid

Pours a creamy golden color like butterscotch with a good head that linger like a creamy pancake. Smells of spicy stonefruit pulp. Medium nectar with excellent carbonation. This is a solid brew with complex nuances of green apples, banana, nectarine, and mild white spice. Good stuff. Very drinkable on a hot day like today.
Draft.  Golden, clear, no head.  Smooth and slighlty sweet, coats the mouth.  Clean finish, mild aroma.  Nice beer.

On tap at Novare Res.  Orange-ish with white head and lace.  Mild fruity sweet vanilla orange bready with spicy herbal complex mildly bitter finish.  Avoids the offensively bitter lingering astringency of many spiced beers and the bland sweetnes of many bieres de garde.  Extremely and subtly complex and delicious.  Excellent.

Draught pour is slightly cloudy amber with whitish head.  Aromas are herbal and light.  Taste is herbs, sweet Belgian yeastiness, and grass.  Very nice balance and mixture of flavors to make it interesting.  Overall another winner for this great brewery.
On tap at TJs. Unfortunately, I got the dregs of the keg. Light gold, frothy head, decent lacing. Aromas of citrus, floral, grass, rye. Light on the palate. Taste is fairly subdued.

Pours a clear golden, very lively, with a nice small head, great retention... Yeasty, lightly medicinal, light fruits... Fruity, bubblegum flavor, yeasty, has a lightly eggy feel... medium full bodied, somewhat lively...

At the GRNY festival.  The aroma is musty, horseblanket.  The appearance is hazy yellow, white head.  The flavor is like the aroma, but with some lemon, flowers.  medium in body.  The beer finishes with a sour, vinegar like quality.  Interesting.  Not as floral as I might have thought.
Draft at Closed for Business. Pours a deep gold with an off white head. Scent is floral with lemons. Taste is fruit and spices.
Tap at RnH - orange gold pour, nose is nice funk. Caramel, some sulfur, barnyard, nice earth, bready malts.
Draft. Pours golden orange with an off white head. Fruity and floral aroma, with herbal and lighter lemony citric notes. The flavor has spicy yeast, fruit, and nice flowery notes. Really good.

On tap at The Thirsty Monk in Asheville.  Pours an intense golden orange, with a hint of red, as if just a hint of hibiscus was thrown in the mix, and the taste and nose suggest perhaps the same... but just a bit.  Nose shows more honey and mixed interesting grain.  A bit of hay/barnyard and floral notes.  Lots of citrus.  Similar taste, but a bit more sweet and fruity.  Intense and subdued at the same time.  Soft palate.  Great.
Draft at Paradiso Dupont.  Cloudy, variegated orange color.  Aroma of hay, orange peel/citrus.  Taste has lots of malt, citrus, flowers.  Nice stuff.
